Quick Guide: Adding a New Blog Post

Creating a New Blog Entry

Step 1: Create the File

Create a new file in _blog/_posts/ with this naming format:

YYYY-MM-DD-your-post-title.md

Example: 2024-12-20-ai-update.md

Step 2: Add the Template

Copy this template into your new file:

---
title: "Your Post Title Here"
date: 2024-12-20
description: "A brief description that shows in previews and search results"
tags: [optional, tags, here]
layout: post.njk
permalink: /blog/2025/11//index.html
---

Write your blog post content here using Markdown.

## Heading Example

You can use **bold**, *italic*, and [links](https://example.com).

- Lists work
- Just like this

### Subheading

More content...

Step 3: Write Your Content

  • Write in Markdown below the front matter (the --- section)
  • Use headings (## for main sections, ### for subsections)
  • Add links, lists, and formatting as needed

Step 4: Test Locally (Optional)

npm run build
npm run serve

Then visit http://localhost:8080/blog/ to see your new post

Step 5: Commit and Push

git add _blog/_posts/YYYY-MM-DD-your-post-title.md
git commit -m "Add new blog post: Your Post Title"
git push

GitHub Deployment

Current Setup

Your GitHub Actions workflow is already configured! It will:

  • ✅ Automatically build when you push to main branch
  • ✅ Generate the blog HTML from your markdown
  • ✅ Deploy to GitHub Pages automatically

What You Need to Configure (One-Time Setup)

  1. Enable GitHub Pages:

    • Go to your GitHub repository
    • Click Settings → Pages
    • Under "Source", select: GitHub Actions

  2. Push to Main Branch:

    • When you push your new blog post to the main branch, it will automatically:
      • Build the site (Tailwind CSS + Eleventy)
      • Generate your blog post
      • Deploy to GitHub Pages

Workflow Summary

1. Create markdown file → 2. Push to GitHub → 3. GitHub Actions builds & deploys → 4. Live!

That's it! No manual deployment steps needed after the initial setup.

Notes

  • File naming: Always use YYYY-MM-DD-title.md format
  • Front matter: Copy it exactly as shown (don't modify the permalink line)
  • Tags: Currently not displayed, but you can add them for future use
  • Date: Use the actual publication date in YYYY-MM-DD format
  • URL: Your post will be available at /blog/YYYY/MM/post-title/

Example Post Structure

_blog/_posts/
├── 2024-12-15-welcome-to-messy-blog.md  ← Existing
└── 2024-12-20-your-new-post.md          ← Your new post

After building, it becomes:

_site/blog/
├── index.html
└── 2024/
    └── 12/
        ├── welcome-to-the-messy-blog/
        │   └── index.html
        └── your-new-post/
            └── index.html

Need help? Check _blog/README.md for more detailed documentation.
